DOC.HEAD: New Romanian Gov't Gains Support but Executions Criticized
Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, By late ... and INSERTS 2 grafs after 23rd graf, `Britain, Chile ... to UPDATE with North Korean recognition.
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Several nations and the human rights group Amnesty International criticized Romania's new leaders Tuesday for executing dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife without a public trial, saying a free Romania should live by the rule of law. But there also were expressions of understanding of the treatment meted out to the Ceausescus, and the country's new government gained increasing international support. By Wednesday, at least 18 countries _ including such past Ceausescu supporters as China, North Korea and Iran _ had recognized Romania's National Salvation Committee, which overthrew Ceausescu Friday following a popular uprising. Tons of international aid streamed into Romania. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a message to Romania's leader of the new provisional government, Ion Iliescu, noting that he ``took charge of the country at a difficult moment when Romanian patriots resolutely came out to save the nation from forces of despotism and terror.'' In the message, carried by the official news agency Tass, Gorbachev assured the new government of Soviet support. The Soviet Foreign Ministry called the executions of the Ceausescus an internal affair. Spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said the decision ``has probably been made taking into account the aspirations and will of the Romanian people.'' The United States joined several nations in criticizing the secret trial, and the Italian office of Amnesty International deplored the executions. ``The idea that the use of the death penalty can survive during the passage from the old regime to a democratic system provokes worry,'' the human rights group said. The Dutch government said it was ``concerned'' and expressed hope that ``the high principles of the rule of law will find their place in the new Romania for which so many have fought to the utmost.'' The Dutch said, however, that Ceausescu was responsible ``for the inhuman suffering inflicted on the Romanian people'' and said they were ``willing to take into account the possible connection'' between his death and efforts to quickly end ``the senseless bloodshed'' caused by elite police units loyal to the dictator. In Britain, a Foreign Office spokesman said normal accepted standards were difficult during ``a civil war situation.'' ``Although one may regret a secret trial, at the time it was not really surprising,'' said a Foreign Office spokesman, who by custom was not identified. But George Robertson of the opposition Labor Party called the secret trial ``a sad birth to the new nation.'' Iolanda Stranescu, president of the British Romanian Association, echoed his assessment, saying: ``Our feeling is Ceausescu should have had a public trial. It is not an excellent start for the new government.'' Fund-raising for Romania gained momentum worldwide. Two West German military planes carrying medical supplies and other relief equipment landed in Bucharest Tuesday and the German Red Cross prepared a convoy to leave by land. The British Red Cross, which launched an appeal Saturday, said Tuesday that it had received as many as 12,000 callers an hour and had raised more than $700,000. It said it had sent 30 tons of drugs and medical supplies to Romania. Libya's official news agency JANA said Libya was sending a planeload of medicine. Libya again denied that Libyans were participating in events in Romania on the side of the pro-Ceausescu forces, JANA said. Czechoslovakia sent two cargo planes with medical aid and food to Bucharest, following two trains and ambulance convoys sent over the weekend, the official CTK news agency said. In Israel, where 400,000 Romanian immigrants and their descendants live, a two-hour radio show was held Tuesday to seek donations and pass on information about Jews in Romania. Israel's Foreign Ministry planned to send a six-ton shipment of medical supplies to Bucharest. Israel Radio said two Romanian-speaking doctors would accompany the supplies. Britain, Chile, China, Colombia, Greece, Hungary, Spain and Iran on Tuesday joined the United States, the Soviet Union and at least nine other nations in pledging support for the National Salvation Committee. On Wednesday, the official (North) Korean Central News Agency said communist North Korea recognized the new government. KCNA was monitored in Tokyo. ``We respect the road chosen by the Romanian people and recognize the Council of the Romanian National Salvation Front as the representative of the Romanian people,'' read a statement of the North Korean Foreign Ministry, quoted by the agency. Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said in a statement that hostilities between Hungary and Romania were at an end, and pledged his government's support for the new leadership. Relations between the two countries were traditionally strained over Hungary's claims that the ethnic Hungarian minority in Romania was discriminated against under Ceausescu. Tensions aggravated as Hungary increasingly embraced democratic reforms while Ceausescu remained staunchly opposed to such reforms. Iran announced its recognition hours after dismissing its ambassador to Bucharest for failing to inform Tehran of growing opposition to Ceausescu before he visited Iran last week. Parliament demanded that Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati explain why Ceausescu was warmly received by Iranian officials. The Foreign Ministry, announcing recognition of the new government, said relations between the two countries ``will expand.'' Romania was Iran's second-biggest trading partner in Eastern Europe and during Ceausescu's visit he signed an agreement to buy 1 million barrels of oil and 1 billion cubic meters of gas a year. The Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday it was ``ready to continue to maintain and develop its friendly relations with Romania.'' Ceausescu maintained good relations with Beijing over decades of hostility between China and the rest of the Soviet bloc and was one of the few socialist leaders to praise the Chinese leadership's crackdown of the student-led pro-democracy movement in June.
